ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The class was well designed. The special lecturers who came to give lectures were very frank and we could deal with everything about the organizations, which was very helpful to understand conservation strategies.
I loved this class. It should be offered regularly.
I believe this course will be valuable to anyone doing conservation work anywhere. Few if any of the lectures had lessons that could only be applied to the tropics.

the opportunity for small lunches with the speakers was amazing! i was able to access people from the big NGOs that i had read about, and finally had a chance to understand the operations from their perspective. i felt like one of the best parts of the course was the personal network i made, as well as an excellent overview of the key issues conservationists have struggled with, particularly since the mid90s, particularly in regards to protected areas. and i actually really appreciated the readings.
The speakers were by and large fantastic.

Getting to work on a project for an organization. Applying some of the more general concepts I had read about in a specific project helped me relate to them better and understand their real-life function.
Guest speakers, lunches with the speakers, and a wonderful instructor!
great lectures in part 1 of the course

Ability to talk to a lot of professionals in the field, get some real world contacts, and keep up to date on current issues in conservation.Adaptive management sessions were useful, and there should be more participatory activities for the class (field trip?).
Covering topics that are otherwise neglected by the FES curriculum - both in terms of themes, and geographies (i.e. the tropics).
Being exposed to many practitioners and going beyond theory.
The open format for assignments. There was lots of freedom about how we could complete assignments.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: some of the speakers weren't amazing. i was really excited to have the foundations of success folks come; now i know, unequivocally, that i have no interest in taking any courses they teach, which i suppose is good knowledge--but disappointing. similarly i thought the course was dominated by the big ngos. which was great for me, as i've had a left coast, grassroots-groups perspective, but i'd think it could be good to get someone from cultural survival, maybe some other smaller groups that often find themselves on the other side of the divide. in fact, getting one or two panels for the classes that will be a bit controversial, rather than one perspective, could be valuable, too. but largely i don't think much needs to be changed. i really enjoyed the ega person, but i'm not sure others did.also, the response papers probably could have been structured in a better way. i didn't think the format, with select students intending to kick off the conversation, functioned very well.
The course needs to attract a wider range of students.
the "foundations of success" modules were painful to sit through

Need to shorten the number and length of presentations a little bit, and maybe gear the course more toward the projects. Make students pick a project more quickly, and concentrate on fewer but more cross-cutting and group work. Encourage guest lecturers to go outside of their comfort zone a bit, instead of just talking about what they do on a daily basis in their office.It was not acceptable to have 9 hours of mandatory class time during reading and finals week. For a couple of the topics, two speakers could definitely be consolidated into one, and the presentations should just take place during the last normal class period.Marina should have felt more free to take control of class sessions, share more about her Rainforest Alliance work, and push discussion a bit more.
Some (2-3) of the speakers were just really unengaging and uninteresting, and made for rather wearisome 3 hour classes.
Fewer guest speakers, and instead have instructor lead more lectures and discussions.
Maintaining a clear conceptual momentum and pace with a class with mostly guest speakers can be challenging.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: solid.
Both Marina Campos and Sarah Wyatt were always responsive when I asked them for help.
Very good
Both very available, though Marina was only available Mondays, generally.
Super available! I had excellent discussions with instructor and TA outside of the classroom that was both helpful and enjoyable.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I came to Yale to focus on tropical forest conservation, and this was the only class I've taken in my two years that squarely focuses on what i wanted to know--policy and project-based approaches to conservation. so my only request would be to have more like this. i really think that, should marina be willing, this class be taught again.
For those who study the tropics, this course was indispensable and covered information that no other class at FES does.
i'm intrested in working on tropical conservation projects
This class many aspects of tropical conservation, especially regarding the functional and practical aspects, which were very relevant for students like me who intend to work in this field.

This course is another set of skills used to do conservation in a different area or the world. Although it is not a terribly unique class in that way, it does focus on pragmatic skills that aren't often talked about in other courses.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: see above
I took this course because I had little experience in or knowledge of the practical aspects of conservation projects, and I wanted to learn more from experts in the field.
You can't pass up tropical-focused courses when they are offered.
to continue learning about tropical conservation strategies
Wanted to keep up to date on current tropical and conservation issues/paradigms.
The topic was interesting, and it filled a gap in the curriculum.
Interest in conservation

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes, i was definitely happy with my experience. i also appreciated the assignment to work on a client-based project. though i struggled in the beginning finding a good fit, when i did latch onto something (post spring break, a change), i was fascinated by the topic.
It definitely did. I wanted to hear from a large number of practitioners about their work in tropical conservation. I learned a lot and enjoyed the process.
Exceeded
yes
For the most part yes, although I should have picked a project topic more quickly.
Somewhat. Understanding that it was an experiement, a new class, it was good, and I hope there are opportunities for the class to continue and be refined and improved in future sessions.
Definitely

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes.
Yes
not really, i expected something more, although i'm not quite sure what
I did not expect to be as engaged with outside speakers and professional, so that was a great plus.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: again, the foundations of success modules (2 weeks!) were painful to sit through, and could have at least been made more relevant by using a tropical example
Keeps people on task and on schedule, and you can maybe accomplish a lot more for the client in the semester. This class should be more like a clinic class.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do all of the readings

Start working on the final project from the beginning, making sure to ask exactly what the sponsoring organization wants in their final product. Take advantage of the weekly lunches with the guest speakers  you might find contacts that could lead to future jobs.
Do all readings which is very helpful to unserdatnd the concepts that we deal with in the class.
Communicate as much as possible with your NGO, even if they are not very available. At least show them that you are making the effort.
do the reading!
Work in a team on a client issue that's really interesting to you, and start early!
Choose a project of great personal interest, and make sure that it is feasible without relying on far flung email correspondents that may or may not email you back!
Meet as many of the speakers as possible that are related to your interests and even some that aren't.
